HCI

HCI Design Principles

Visibility

Visibility plays a vital role in human-computer interaction design. Interfaces for key features should be visually intuitive so that users should know how to acess them just by looking at the interface.
To apply this principle to our project, our major features should be obviously and visiblily displayed in the user interfaces. For functionalities like adding appointment, we place a button labeled 'add new appointment' at the top of the page so that it clear and noticeable for the users . To make our filter functionalities more visible, we desgined search bars with placeholder sayings 'search patients by name'or 'search by appointment ID' along with buttons.

simplicity and consistancy

Simplicity is especially important for our workflow management webapp. Our client ocularists are busy and want to spend less time on booking processes. so that the HCI design should provides them easy access to their goals with least steps. The UI structure should stay simple and non confusing. We designed intuitive navigation bar with sensible naming for each webpages. It also highlights current page so that the interfaces are consist.

Feedback

A good HCI design should provide feedbacks when users made an action to show whether the action is successful or not. For our webapp,Ocularists and admins should be notified whether or not their modifications to appointments and patients are successful. Feedbacks can be pop up windows or a special sound effect.

Our Sketches

We drew sketches for my rota and team rota page considering HCI design priciple. Our sketch allows ocularists to easily see their schedules for the day. We designed a highlighted pointer to the current location in the rota. This rota tells the user what slot they are in currently, without having to cross-check with a watch or clock. The idea of “clicking on a slot to see the information” allows user to be presented with an abstracted view but also have the flexibility to view and edit the information at a granular level. We also came up with the idea of a notice box. This will keep Ocularists up to date to any changes in appointments.

First Prototype

First we created a prototype using balsamiq. We presented this prototype and all of our sketches to the users. When we reviewed this prototype we found that it is very similar to the current system, this is the system that the users already have so many problems with. However, they particularly liked features from one of the more updated sketches this meant we had to consider alternatives and we created another prototype.

Second Prototype

After considering the feedback from the users on the first prototype, we created a new prototype of the system. User feedback suggested that too much information was shown at once. To fix this problem we kept relevant data together and added expandable menus, scroll bars, checkboxes and search fields. This functionality helps the user view only the information that they want to see, therefore it solves the largest concern that users had with with last design.

Previous Next

Evaluation of Prototype

We used heuristics evaluation to evaluate out prototypes

Heuristic problem Solution Severity
Flexibility and Efficiency of Use Ocularist should be able to filter the information about the patient, to view only the relevant information about one patient. Add filter functionality to view patient page. 2
Visibility of System Status Need an option for a user to mark patient as arrived. Add an “Arrived” checkbox next to each patient in the rota. 1
User Control and Freedom Need the ability to change an appointment type and/or the ocularist that the appointment is booked with. Added an edit appointment option to each appointment in the team rota. 2
